docs.lead_paragraph: To hear the teachers tell it, the jailing of more than 130 striking school employees since Monday is only the latest in a long history of shabby treatment at the hands of the Board of Education here. The current contract dispute over increased teacher payments for health insurance benefits has seemed almost incidental to the list of past grievances, some stretching back years, that are bitterly pouring out in a Freehold courtroom as teachers protest the slow pace of bargaining now and in previous years.

headline.main: Teachers' Strike Grows Angrier, But Support of Residents Is Elusive

docs.abstract: Article discusses teachers strike in Middletown, NJ, where more than 130 school employees have been jailed; current contract dispute over increased teacher payments for health insurance is overshadowed by past grievances and teachers protest slow pace of bargaining; residents voice little sympathy for strikers; photo (M)

byline.original: By ROBERT HANLEY and ANDREW JACOBS

docs.lead_paragraph: Despite signs of financial improvement over the last year, New Jersey's 81 community hospitals may lose money or narrow their profits because of likely cutbacks in state aid and the additional costs of preparing for bioterrorism, the New Jersey Hospital Association said. The hospitals posted nearly $115 million in profit on $11.7 billion of revenues in 2000, up from a $257 million loss in 1999, according to a report released Monday by the association. The profits were due to several one-time increases in Medicare reimbursements and the sale of a hospital-malpractice insurance company.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Profit Outlook For Hospitals

docs.abstract: New Jersey Hospital Assn announces that community hospitals may lose money or narrow profits because of likely cutbacks in state aid and added costs in preparing for bioterrorism (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: The proposal by the nation's biggest steel makers to have the government pick up billions of dollars in retiree health costs was greeted with skepticism in Washington and among other industries yesterday. Executives at some of the largest steel companies are seeking government support to consolidate up to five ailing steel makers into one big company on more solid footing. Critical to the plan is a proposal to shift the burden for retiree health care costs -- estimated at up to $13 billion -- to the government.

headline.main: Rivals and Others Criticize Steel Makers' Bid for U.S. Aid

docs.abstract: Proposal by nation's biggest steel makers to have government pick up billions of dollars in retiree health costs is greeted with skepticism in Washington and among other industries; executives at some of largest steel companies, including Bethlehem Steel, US Steel unit of USX and Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel, are seeking government support to consolidate up to five ailing steel makers into one big company on more solid footing; critical to plan is proposal to shift burdern of retiree health care costs--estimated at up to $13 billion--to government; Washington analysts, steel users and even some other steel makers criticize plan, which they say would benefit small group of companies at expense of even larger group of steel users and of taxpayers in general; Nucor chief executive Dan DiMicco denounces plan; Urban Institute president Robert D Reischauer says plan will not be approved by Congress; Repr Peter J Visclosky, backer of plan, says he is desperate to have relief passed by end of year; photo (M)
docs.snippet: The proposal by the nation's biggest steel makers to have the government pick up billions of dollars in retiree health costs was greeted with skepticism in Washington and among other industries yesterday.    Executives at some of the largest steel...

docs.lead_paragraph: House Republican leaders offered to spend about $25 billion to aid the unemployed today as the two main economic issues before Congress -- trade powers for the president and stimulating the domestic economy -- merged in furious end-of-session horse trading. Representative Bill Thomas, the California Republican who is chairman of the House Way and Means Committee, offered to support far more spending to aid jobless workers and help them pay for health care than Republicans favored as recently as October. Mr. Thomas also unveiled a separate measure, which he valued at over $2 billion, to aid workers who lose jobs because of imports or the attacks on Sept. 11.

headline.main: $25 Billion to Aid the Jobless Is Backed by House G.O.P. Leaders

It begins and ends with the Port Authority, which is not known for amorous liaisons. It involves a mail deliverer, a secretary and the skyscrapers of New York.

docs.lead_paragraph: As members of a small union representing teachers at 10 Roman Catholic high schools struck for the fourth day yesterday, the New York Archdiocese found itself tangled in another labor dispute with a larger union whose protest could cripple instruction at far more schools. About three dozen teachers at one high school and two elementary schools represented by the Federation of Catholic Teachers called in sick yesterday over contract disputes involving medical insurance and pay, the union said. Teachers at two other schools represented by the federation called in sick on Monday.

headline.main: Union Grievances Could Prompt Wider Strike at Catholic Schools

docs.abstract: New York Archdiocese, as members of Lay Faculty Assn continue strike at 10 Roman Catholic high schools, is faced with labor unrest from larger Federation of Catholic Teachers (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The theme of the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s convention is written in huge letters behind the ballroom's podium: America's Workers -- Heroes Every Day. Those words aim not only to honor the firefighters and others who died responding to the Sept. 11 attacks, but also to capitalize on the improved standing of millions of blue-collar and government workers.

headline.main: During a Blue-Collar Upswing, Labor Seeks a Lift

docs.abstract: State of labor movement discussed as AFL-CIO holds convention, Las Vegas; union membership has dropped to 13.5 percent of work force, down from 14.9 percent in 1995, despite increased organizing efforts under John J Sweeney, AFL-CIO president; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: As President Bush corners lawmakers on the White House dance floor and on Air Force One to urge them to back his bid for enhanced trade authority, his administration is warning that if Congress rejects the proposal this week ''no one will negotiate'' with the United States on trade. The House has scheduled a vote Thursday on whether to grant the president what is known as trade promotion authority, giving him the power to reach trade deals that Congress could accept or reject, but not amend.

headline.main: As Vote Nears, Bush Presses for New Trade Powers

docs.abstract: Pres Bush is pressing Congress for power to reach trade deals that Congress can accept or reject, but not amend; is still some 20 votes short of majority as House vote nears; administration is warning that world will cut United States out of trade deals unless Congress cooperates (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Struggling with bankruptcies and hurt by foreign imports, the nation's biggest steel companies said yesterday that they were asking the Bush administration and Congress to back a plan allowing up to half a dozen steel makers to merge into a single company and to shift billions of dollars in retiree health care costs to the government. The companies' executives have met in recent weeks with Bush cabinet members and Congressional leaders to gain support for a plan that would fundamentally reshape an industry that has been barely profitable in the last decade and has logged further losses since Sept. 11.

headline.main: Steel Producers Seek a Merger, With U.S. Help

docs.abstract: Nation's biggest steel companies, struggling with bankruptcies and foreign imports, ask Bush administration and Congress to back plan allowing up to half dozen manufacturers to merge into single company and to shift billions fo dollars in retiree health care costs to government; executives say plan is needed to transform fragmented industry of small producers into one of fewer, but larger, American steel makers that would be better able to compete with larger rivals in Europe and Asia; say industry needs to be rid of costs of retiree health care benefits, currently estimated at $13 billion, that have prevented many financially struggling companies from merging; those involved in talks include US Steel unit of USX Corp, Bethlehem Steel and Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel (M)
docs.snippet: Struggling with bankruptcies and hurt by foreign imports, the nation's biggest steel companies said yesterday that they were asking the Bush administration and Congress to back a plan allowing up to half a dozen steel makers to merge into a single...

docs.lead_paragraph: Pressed by employers, some of the nation's biggest insurers are introducing a new kind of health plan that would significantly change the way employees are reimbursed for ordinary medical expenses. Most working families, who have relatively low medical bills, could save money under the plans. But those with several thousand dollars in medical expenses could wind up paying much more.

headline.main: A New Health Plan May Raise Expenses For Sickest Workers

docs.abstract: Some of nation's biggest insurers, pressed by employers, are introducing new kind of health plans that would significantly change way employees are reimbursed for ordinary medical expenses; plans would allow most working families with relatively low medical bills to save money, but those with several thousand dollars in expenses could wind up paying much more; typically require family to pay annual premium of $1,000 to 1,400, slightly lower than cost of traditional medical care and gives it allowance of $2,000 to $3,000 each year to spend on medical expenses; family must cover every cost above cap, sometimes up to $5,000 or more; after higher amount is reached, employer picks up most of bills; family that keeps medical bills lower than allowance can roll over any unspent money to pay medical bills in future years; other aspects of plans discussed; insurers include Aetna, Humana, Cigna, UnitedHealth Group and Wellpoint Health Networks (M)
